**G.L. c. 208, \u00a728**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 208, §28**, **G.L. c. 209C, §20**, and **G.L. c. 215, §6** to modify prior custody and visitation orders where a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the welfare of the children.

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a720**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 208, §28**, **G.L. c. 209C, §20**, and **G.L. c. 215, §6** to modify prior custody and visitation orders where a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the welfare of the children.

**G.L. c. 215, \u00a76**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 208, §28**, **G.L. c. 209C, §20**, and **G.L. c. 215, §6** to modify prior custody and visitation orders where a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the welfare of the children.

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**, and **Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)**, modification of custody or visitation is appropriate where circumstances have substantially changed and continued enforcement of the existing order is not in the child’s best interests.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on whether there is "cause shown" by determining if removal is in the children’s best interests. It does not discuss the general standard for modification of custody or visitation orders based on a substantial change in circumstances plus best interests; that language appears only in a quoted ALI Principle regarding relocation constituting a substantial change, not as a broad Massachusetts rule for all custody/visitation modifications. Thus, Mason does not itself establish the proposition about when modification of custody or visitation is appropriate.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]… (4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**, and **Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)**, modification of custody or visitation is appropriate where circumstances have substantially changed and continued enforcement of the existing order is not in the child’s best interests.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Rosenthal does address standards for modifying custody orders, but it does not state the Mason formulation that modification is appropriate where there has been a substantial change in circumstances and continued enforcement of the existing order is not in the child’s best interests. Instead, it applies G.L. c. 208, § 28 and prior case law, requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification be necessary in the child’s best interests. The case actually reverses a modification for lack of such a change; it does not articulate the "continued enforcement" language used in Mason, so it does not cleanly support the combined proposition as phrased.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a731**.proposition: The conduct described violates the principle that custody and visitation shall at all times promote the **best interests of the children**, consistent with **G.L. c. 208, §31**, and **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..proposition: The conduct described violates the principle that custody and visitation shall at all times promote the **best interests of the children**, consistent with **G.L. c. 208, §31**, and **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 208, § 31 and explains that custody/visitation decisions, including removal from the Commonwealth, must be based on the children’s best interests, explicitly integrating that standard into its analysis of custody and relocation. The court emphasizes that the children’s best interests remain the paramount concern and describes how those interests are evaluated in light of the custodial parent’s circumstances, which is consistent with the proposition cited.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”}

**Sawyer v. Sawyer, 448 Mass. 1001 (2006.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon proof of a **material and substantial change of circumstances** under **G.L. c. 208, §28** and **Sawyer v. Sawyer, 448 Mass. 1001 (2006)**.
**Sawyer v. Sawyer, 448 Mass. 1001 (2006.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sawyer v. Sawyer reproduced here involves a G.L. c. 211, § 3 petition relating to a wrongful death default judgment following a murder conviction. It does not concern Probate and Family Court, custody, G.L. c. 208, § 28, or modification of custody judgments based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, this case does not support the cited custody-modification proposition and appears to be a mis-citation or unrelated authority.
**Sawyer v. Sawyer, 448 Mass. 1001 (2006.relevant_excerpt: “Snell then filed his petition in the county court. In that petition, he asked the single justice to order the clerk in the Superior Court to docket his motions and pleadings in the wrongful death case. The single justice denied relief without a hearing. … Moreover, ‘[i]t is settled that ‘relief under G. L. c. 211, § 3, is extraordinary and may not be sought as a substitute for normal appellate review….’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification is the **best interests of the child** (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976)).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly characterizes the ‘best interests of the child’ as the governing standard in custody determinations, describing it as the longstanding, paramount concern in such cases. The court reaffirms that custody awards must be based on this best-interests standard and discusses how statutory factors inform, but do not replace, that paramount inquiry. This directly supports the proposition that the paramount consideration in custody (and thus any change in custody) is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification is the **best interests of the child** (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976)).
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody determinations the governing and dominating rule is the welfare of the child, describing it as the controlling consideration for the judge. While this case is a primary custody determination rather than a post-judgment modification, the articulated principle is the same “best interests/welfare of the child” standard that governs custody orders, including their modification. Thus, the case properly supports the proposition that the paramount consideration is the child’s best interests.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … [T]he happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Courts have recognized the need to intervene when the environment during parenting time endangers a child’s emotional or physical health (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that domestic violence and exposure to it cause serious harm to children and must be explicitly considered in custody determinations. The court remands precisely because the lower court failed to make explicit findings on how the abusive environment affected the child and the risks posed by custody with the abusive parent. This aligns with the proposition that courts recognize the need to intervene when the parenting environment endangers a child’s emotional or physical health.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Courts have recognized the need to intervene when the environment during parenting time endangers a child’s emotional or physical health (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the “best interests of the child” standard in custody and visitation and expressly upholds restrictions on the father’s visitation where the circumstances and some incidents during visitation were “inconsistent with the best interests of the children.” The court affirms that, when parents’ conduct or the environment during visitation is contrary to the children’s welfare, the judge may limit parenting time, thereby recognizing the need to intervene to protect the child’s well-being, including health and development.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order… ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’… [I]ncidents inconsistent with the best interests of the children (e.g., substandard personal hygiene) occurred during certain extended periods when the husband was exercising his visitation rights….”}

*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).proposition: The presence of individuals with violent histories or volatile behavior can justify supervised visitation or restriction of exposure (*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); *Custody of Eleanor*, 414 Mass. 795 (1993)).
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Vito discusses when courts may order or decline postadoption contact and emphasizes that any such contact must be in the child’s best interests, but it does not analyze or base a visitation decision on the presence of individuals with violent histories or volatile behavior. The factual and legal discussion centers on lack of emotional bonding, cultural and racial identity concerns, and the child’s attachment to the foster family, not safety risks from violent or volatile individuals. Thus, it does not provide authority for restricting contact specifically because of violent histories or volatile behavior.
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Where, as here, the child has formed strong, nurturing bonds with his preadoptive family, and there is little or no evidence of a significant, existing bond with the biological parent, judicial exercise of equitable power to require postadoption contact would usually be unwarranted.… A necessary condition is a finding, supported by the evidence, that continued contact is currently in the best interests of the child.”

*Custody of Eleanor*, 414 Mass. 795 (199.proposition: The presence of individuals with violent histories or volatile behavior can justify supervised visitation or restriction of exposure (*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); *Custody of Eleanor*, 414 Mass. 795 (1993)).
*Custody of Eleanor*, 414 Mass. 795 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses Flanders’s psychiatric history, sexual offender profile, and a professional recommendation that he not have unsupervised access to children, and it notes that the Juvenile Court ordered Flanders have no contact with the children. However, the Supreme Judicial Court’s decision is focused on the standard of review and the sufficiency of evidence of parental unfitness, not on articulating a legal rule that violent or volatile individuals’ presence justifies supervised visitation or restricted exposure. The case thus uses the dangerous third party as factual background rather than establishing the cited legal proposition.
*Custody of Eleanor*, 414 Mass. 795 (199.relevant_excerpt: “After a full hearing, the judge granted temporary custody of Eleanor and Carol to the department, ordered that they be placed in foster care, required that their visits with their mother be supervised, and ordered Flanders to have no contact with either child. … Dr. Doolittle concluded, ‘The circumstances to [Flanders’] emotional adjustment as well as the characteristics outlined above suggest the need for considerable caution regarding his having unsupervised access to children at the present time.’ He recommended that Flanders not be granted unsupervised access to children residing in his home.”

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: A parent’s right to custody or visitation is not absolute and must yield to the child’s safety and welfare (*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)).
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth after divorce (real-advantage and best-interests analysis) and the weight to be given to a custodial parent’s remarriage. It discusses parental interests and due process rights but does not articulate or apply a rule that a parent’s custody or visitation rights must yield to the child’s safety or welfare, nor does it frame any limitation on parental rights in those terms. The case is therefore not good authority for the specific proposition about parental rights yielding to child safety and welfare.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711. In addition, ‘the interests of the noncustodial parent must be considered.’”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: A parent’s right to custody or visitation is not absolute and must yield to the child’s safety and welfare (*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that custody determinations turn on the child’s best interests and welfare, not on any absolute parental entitlement. In affirming the custody award, the court focuses on the harm to the child from the mother’s conduct (wrongful removal, instability, alienation) and expressly endorses awarding custody to the parent who can best support the child’s overall needs, even though both parents are legal parents. This aligns with the principle that parental rights to custody/visitation must yield to the child’s safety and welfare.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ … The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’”}
